content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've had this game for a while know, ever since it was called Incognita, and I gotta tell you, this game has evolved massively since then.  It used to be a kind of turnbased rpg where the goal was more or less "complete goal X then leave the building" but now it is more of a roguelike, but it has an amazing twist on the genre.  Since you play as a spy, and most teams don't even start with weapons, you have to us stealth, hacking, and lock-picking to make it through the hostile buildings you find yourself in.  This might sound boring, sneak in and out while gathering anything you can, but it leads to some absurdly tense moments.  One such moment for myself was when I had been spotted and knocked out one guard while I had another one already knocked out but I couldn't just leave them knocked out because they would wake up 2 turns from one another blowing my cover completely so I waited maybe 20 minutes trying to make a plan to escape, I failed.  Two agents permanently gone.  It's a wonderful game and I recommend it to roguelike fans, stealth fans, and tactics fans.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												A great turn-based tactics that looks like a mix of XCOM and Splinter Cell. You control several agents as they infiltrate and pillage different facilities.The main campaign is really short (5-6 hours tops), but there's an endless mode. Even better, all locations are randomly generated with different rooms, guards, cameras, security bots. etc. This adds a lot of replayability, especially since there are 4 preset difficulties and you can tailor a custom difficulty by changing various game settings.You also unlock new agents and AI abilities (programs & hacks) by getting XP for completed missions. So each time you start a new game, not only you can choose other difficulty settings, but different agents and abilities as well.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												[Edit : Suggested Strategy at the bottom]Invisible Inc is a very good surprise. I usually enjoy team-based tactical games, and this blend of stealth and hacking is really engaging for me.I think the game truly shines by the way it manages tension. During a mission, even if you can crawl and hack your way discretely to your objectives, the alarm level still rises and you're only a turn away from a very stressed situation where guards surrounds you and make you sweat like hell.  In between mission, since you have a time limit, you'll have to make tough choices between gaining access to facilities, acquiring money, items or improving your agents.Depth and replay value comes from the procedural map generation and the multiple improvements for your agents (skills, augments, items) or your IA (programs), The art direction is excellent and really contributes to the game's readability (an important feature since you have to monitor multiple agents, sometimes in different places, and also the Incognita network).Suggested Strategy (for casual play)- Choose Beginner Mode- Start with Internationale and Banks- Start with Power Drip (+1 Power / turn) and Parasite (Progressive hack) // Flow- Use Internationale to "scout" doors and surroundings ; Use Parasite to hack Cameras, shops (items or programs), Safes, eventually Drones - forget the sound bugs - you can walk pass them.- Use Banks to "knock out" guards, drag them and paralyze them ; and also, check locked doors and eventually unlock them.// Development- Augment Internationale with the ability to gain AP each time you hack a firewall (Network Download) ; equip her with a rechargeable pistol and keep a charge. Internationale should use her weapons only in last resort - her role is to uncover most of the map as fast as possible.- Augment Banks with the ability to reduce item cooldown each time you use one item (Torque Injectors) ; equip her with several neural disruptors.- Buy these programs as fast as you can : Data Blast (-1 Firewall in 5 square radius), Leash (+1 turn to control Drones), Taurus (Move Daemons) - some can be tricky to use and require good timing.// Mission Order- Free another agent as soon as you can !- Remember to buy items and programs in Shops scattered in maps- Go for : Programs, Items and Weapons in that order if possible // Third agent- You cannot control the agent you'll get, so take advantage of their augment. For example, with Shalem, he starts with a +1 Armor Ranged Weapons so I usually give him a rechargeable Rifle up to +2 Armor ; I augment him with a +1 Armor Melee Weapon so I do the same with a Neural Disruptor +2.// Misc Items & Skills- I suggest you first buy skills only when you need them ; later when you have more credits, you could add Strengh (more items, less encumberance, better drag) and Speed (more APs).// Buy & Sell- Remember that you can buy and SELL items to Monst3r, and Shops (regular and super).Well, this is not a complete strategy guide, but I found this combination quite pleasing for casual play :)

												This game is AWESOME!!!!!, If you're a Spy fan this is a must buy. There is a lack of spy games out there and the ones that have come out are about some rouge spy finding out his agency betrayed him now he/she is on the run (boring). Real espionage is about team work and using the resources and intel provided by your agency; Invisible Inc has that and much much MORE!!!!.... Posted: November 5, 2016
												I adore Invisible Inc.! It really has everything you could possibly want from a cyberpunk spy strategy game -- clutch and exciting stealth mechanics, punishingly difficult high-stakes roguelike combat, widely customizable playstyles that bring high replay value, and a really lovely, immersive art direction coupled with a rewarding story mode. Invisible Inc. is a game that looks and feels great and gets better with every replay. I can't sing its praises enough! I highly recommend.

												Highly recommended. Invisible, Inc. must be one of the best turn based strategy games I've played recently. There's a lot of possibility for customisation of play strategy. There is no damage randomisation or so, and you can calculate the outcome of your every turn. The game is quite difficult, and sometimes you can lose due to bad luck (awful gear drops), but invisible Inc. is short and it's easy to start yet another game. Play-through value is high, the levels are random-generated, and there's a lot of starting agents to choose from. With each play-through you even open new characters and in-game hacking software.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												I finished 3 campaings (easy, advanced, expert) in about 7 hours and I don't see what more the game has to offer. Sure you can pump up the difficulty to the max but as the difficulty increases it becomes more and more apparent how RNG plays a huge role to your success. It's no surprise being a rogue-like, indie title but I truly believe the game would be far superior by ditching this tired, attention grabbing strategy. Taking the wrong path to your objectives, rescuing a sub-par agent or not getting a useful item/upgrade can pretty much ruin a run. You can roll with the punches and keep going but you'll feel gimped along the way.In conclusion, the game is too short for the 20 euro pricetag. Getting it for 6 and spending a enjoyable 8 hours with it was perfect for a relaxed gaming weekend but don't expect a memorable experience.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
												The interface and feel are polished and stylized.  It's also a pure stealther, which I normally enjoy.Unfortunately, a number of gameplay issues make it far less fun.First, your success in each mission is far more subject to the luck of the randomizer than your skill.  Every bad level leaves you less prepared for the final one.  In my case, I only had one chance to add an agent so I was also 1 short for the end mission.Second, you can't afford to max out all your agents, so you end up specializing each one.  The problem is, due to the random levels, you split them up to cover ground and just hope the right agent encounters the right stuff.Lastly, it's extremely unclear what is important to improve/buy.  For instance, you might increase an agents loot finding results marginally and then discover that without armor piercing weapons you are unable to handle higher levels.  Then, you "solve" that by exiting levels without clearing them, since the timer makes things dicier the longer you take.This means you get even less resources for subsequent, harder, levels.   Thus compounding the problem into a gloriously pointless end mission.  My first time on the final mission (which just pops on you) I simply did not have enough power to complete the mission.  I was getting +1/turn but it was clearly impossible to finish the first, let alone second, mission objectives.  The only solution is to restart the whole campaign and "try harder" on the lead up missions.  Since the campaign is so short, that's not so bad, but leaves you feeling pretty crappy about the whole experience.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
Invisible Inc. – A Steam Review[Disclamer - I was provided a copy of by the publisher for review purposes]The goodPerfectly tuned turn-based stealth mechanics Unique graphic style – as per Klei’s pedigreeRandomly generated levels offer countless hours of replayabilityThe not so good: The story is generic at bestPlayers need to get used to the idea of a rogue-like turn based stealth game – I found it frustrating to die so many times. Objectively, I’m not the best stealth player ever, but the game was pretty punishing The conclusion: Combining perfectly the spy genre with turn based tactics, ala X-Com, Klei proves once again that they have the stealth gameplay mechanics on lock. Must buy game for fans of the genre, while newcomers might find it a bit punishing.You can see gameplay here -

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												The year is 2074. Corporations own everything. You are part of an underground resistance unit.You break into procedurally generated, corporate buildings. You hack into computer terminals, upgrade character statistics, buy software and weapons and try not to pi** your pants. The tension is palpable. There are three difficulty levels: beginner; experienced; expert. The game is turn-based strategy, with a built-in mechanic to rewind time."Hitman 2: Silent Assassin" meets "Deus Ex" ( 2000 ) meets "X COM: Enemy Unknown" ( 2012 ).I've become horribly addicted to this game and have not showered in a week!

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
												ARE YOU EXPERIENCED?Okay, this is a good game, and I've finished it on beginner in about 24hrs according to steam, I'm playing with dlc and I haven't played it with out before. All seems good. So you beat the game and then sink another 6 hrs in to experienced mode.  Two problems, one, the disconnect from coming from super powered agents way back to basic agents on a harder difficulty setting is jarring, you make too many mistakes.Second is just how hard this is with out level resets, and the difficulty seems to have been adjusted too much, what is a 2nd or 3rd mission is very hard with out the correct hack tool, which you know from beginner you get later... It's not vastly different from beginner, but the combination of disabling level restarts - so you have to start the entire campaign again - and the addition of trying new characters out is too much. Then also the difficult shield level is way out, you don't have the hack tools needed. This can be fixed by enabling level restarts - but then you're not playing experienced you're playing custom, no awards for that.On first play through most people I assume would be doing stealth and avoiding kills, the default characters are this way. You happen to get a couple of characters later which are geared around killing which would be best for a second play through - I just don't see myself playing through beginner again though to get use to it. Also on experienced, even when you ARE experienced, the shield difficulty indicators, the things which tell you how hard something is going to be, were way out. 2nd or 3rd mission in a 2 or 3 level became impossible because I didn't have the right hacking tool (area effect hack), but having played beginner I know that that tool wouldn't be got so early.(I think I got up to turn 37-45 in one map, dragging a body along a map which was basically one long corridor while 8 guards swamped around, a lot of micro. Obviously it wasn't meant to get like that and should rewind before, but it was fun enough to do.)This may be a problem of expectation. Because some in beginner which are marked as "do not advice infiltrating" level 5-6 aren't that hard, yet on experienced a level 2-3, what should have been easy, wasn't. I'm wondering if it would have been better to have started the game on experienced, just so the expectation was set, but even so. Or to have my suped up agents from beginner carry over, just so I could tell if it's the agents or the game.It can sometimes degenerate into a game of drag the body and sit on it, but there are other tools available (like an 8 turn ko syringe)and I'm sure I've not seen even half of them really, it will take a few more play throughs.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Don't listen to those reviews complaining about the difficulty. This game is hard as nails and it owns up to it. This is not a game for the weak of heart, or more critically, the weak of mind. This is not a game that you can sit down and play and expect to have a casual fun time. This is a game that will beat you into the ground until you have that glorious "ah ha!" moment when you finally figure out how to proceed in this game. Once you get over that difficulty hump, this game can be extraordinarily rewarding. That feeling you get when you just barely get your agents and the cash/intel/prisoners to safety is about as exhilerating as a game can get.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
Took me 6 hours to finish this game on Beginner difficulty. I loved every minute of it!I bought this game yesterday at the end of the weekend sale, not too sure if I deemed it worth 12 bucks, but after finishing the campaign on the easiest difficulty in 6 hours (almost in 1 sitting). I'm sure this game is going to played and enjoyed more than you usually get for this kind of price. I tend to divide the price by playtime, to see if a game is worth it's money. GTA V kept me busy for 90 hours at 60 euro, so 0.66 euro per hour. Witcher 3 kept me, so far, occupied for 110 hours for 25 euro, so less than 25 cents per hour. This game will definitely clock in 12+ hours and thus reaching the value of 1 buck per hour - a steal!These days a lot of games are more about graphics than gameplay. This game, though the artstyle is amazing, is definitely more about gameplay. It's basically a turn-based puzzle, where the pieces get mixed after every turn. Progression feels really good and it's almost sad to start over, but the increased difficulty and the unlockables between playthroughs (another level of progression) make it worth it anyway. The random generated levels make playing through the campaign 3 times still a lot of fun.There are a few different missions, which mostly means you get a different rewards for reaching your objective, but apart from that they're all pretty much the same. The beauty in this lies in the random level design. You might get dropped in an impossible situation, where you actually have to trigger an extra alarm, just to continue, because the deactivation station lies out of reach. You will definitely have to use all of your wit combined with your spy gadgets, to finish a level - especially because some of the mechanics are very unforgiving and this gets worse as difficulty increases (a simple misclick can result in the death of an agent).The story is okay, the artstyle is brilliant and the gameplay takes this game home.The developers seem to have a love for bringing really cool games and giving you value for your money, so if you're even slightly interested in this title, definitely pick it up!Too long, did not read?Pros:- Gameplay!- Unique artstyle- Very good replay value- Workshop/mod support- Support indie-titles!- Still receives updates and bugfixesCons:- Short campaign- No multiplayer support- Unable to undo a misclick

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								With a game in beta, it can sometimes be hard to determine whether or not to recommend it.  But Invisible Inc. has some issues that seriously need to be worked out before a full launch.I don't have an issue with hard games.  But what makes Invisible Inc. difficult in its beta has little to do with requirng practice or any skill on the part of the player.  Invisible Inc is difficult in the way that winning on a slot machine in Vegas is difficult: the player is at the mercy of sheer dumb luck.  Even the easiest of missions will have your team dead in two rounds if the random number generator (the floor layout for each mission is randomly generated) is unkind, which is more often than not the case.

number of helpful: 8 of 19 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
												In summary, Adam Jensen found a copy of X-COM ...and augmented himself with it.  The awesomeness was too much for either game, so Invisible, Inc popped back out.  You're welcome.I haven't yet beaten the game, but the *potential* for replayability is immense here.  Given the reviews, I don't expect to be satisified by the story, or even "endless" mode.  Hopefully, a DLC will add some on-going story elements, a campaign, or what this game really needs: A meta-game where your orginization can truly be "Invisible" and play a dangerous game of whittling down the power of the corporations: sabotaging projects, siphoning information, stealing money, ferreting spies, establishing assets, evil corporate DOUBLE AGENTS!, all while keeping your organization's HQ from being wiped out (again) if you leave too much evidence behind.  Lose an agent?  Find him/her and extract before they break under interrogation!  Fail, and it's back into exile w/two random agents.  Corporations, left to themselves, could have power-struggles between them that could allow them to gobble each other up, becoming even more dangerous, and more focused on you.... I could go on and on...@klei - The roots are RIGHT THERE!  I can't recommend this game until something along those lines happens.  I *really* want to.  ...so make me.

Posted: May 28, 2015
												I would dare to say the combat system of this game is better than X-com. 1 square moving, 1 degree line of sight, every aspect of the combat system really makes me say "This is A FXXXing great game." I literally kept saying that during the gameplay.However, a really tragic thing is that there's no story here. Even if the game is great, people need some stairs to reach there. I really want to play more, I really want to try other agents, but combats without story makes this not a game, but rather a labor. I really wish Devs could consider it when they make the next game. If they had written some decent stories and integrated it with the combat system, this game definitely could have been the top 3 game of 2015.Still, system itself is really damn great. I saw another great possibility of 'Klei'. I am hopefully expecting the next game with deep stories and narratives, as a perfect art work. Think of the game 'Skyrim', the show 'Game of throne'. People are thrilled with those Arts because they have stories.Was it really hard to make more stories? I have always hated dirty companies who try scam with DLCs, but I'd gladly buy tons of DLCs of this game because the game itself is absolutely perfect.

number of helpful: 6 of 15 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 11, 2016
												This game is garbage in my opinion, pure and simple. Mind you, i LIKE stealth games, strategy games, turn based game mechanics AND the art style, so this seems like a match made in heaven. Except It's not.It's something about strategy games that try to hurry you up that angers me immensly. It's strategy, aren't I supposed to properly think things through and make plans? Yes? Okay, then why do you give me timers? I am so angry I am almost beyond words.Example: Every five turns something bad happens so you need to hurry up. To get where you need to go you need to knock out 2-3 guards, no avoiding it. The game actively punishes you for killing people by making the timer go faster so you knock them out. Except they only stay knocked out for three rounds unless someone is sitting ontop of them like a schoolyard bully in third grade. Alright, so you either gotta leave someone behind or drag the guard with you. Except you needed to knock out 3 guards and you had three people. Okay, dragging it is then. Except you can only move 3-4 squares at a time while dragging them making the mechanic almost useless. That turn timer is still on by the way.Tick tock.Okay, fine. Leave the guards how bad could it be when they wake up?Three rounds later and they wake up and zero in on you faster than shark smelling blood. ready to crush your hopes and dreams. Okay, maybe i can knock them out again? Nope, they have guns and you do not have the drop on them.Also now the turn timer decided to filter in more guys and reveal your position.Can i run? Nope, one guy is watching the door, that means that if your guys leave the room they get shot. All of them. In a row. By one guy. A guy you knocked out but didn't take his firearm away from him, so he can still hurt you. Yup.Fun.If you enjoy this game, or this synopsis of my experience playing it makes you want to buy it, you may want to consider investing in a multi-tailed whip.Self flaggelation has got to be at LEAST as fun as playing this steaming pile of refuse.That said, i give this game a 5/10. Even if It Is absolute garbage, at least It's functional garbage.Get It If It's under five bucks and you need help taking that last step off the balcony.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												Just finished the game on beginner... felt extremely short. Is there more content if I complete it on a harder difficulty?I was expecting something similar in length to the turn based XCom games, new or old. It felt like 1/10 of that.I read one review that said the game feels a bit "flat", I'd have to agree. There is just not enough stuff in it, actually feels like a well polished first level rather than an entire game.Having said all that I do recommend it, as it's one of the best examples of how to execute a classic turn based squad game. Despite not breaking much new ground, it does what it does well, has good music and personality delivered through the now trademark Klei animations.The game fashions itself as a rogue-like, if I had to guess they were trying to go for replayability on par with something like FTL. Unlike FTL, the game just isn't deep enough to leave me wanting to try it again. I didn't feel like I missed out on anything. There were no paths I felt like I should have taken or challenges I wished I completed. Perhaps these things do exist, but the important thing is that I didn't _feel_ like I missed them or missed out on them. You do get some upgrades in tech, agents and abilities, but they're not nearly as interesting as the ships you unlock in FTL or the tech trees in XCom games.If you can wait for it to go on sale, I would. If you're thinking of making a turn based squad game then you should buy and study it. If you're looking for a fun game to play then paying full price for it doesn't make much sense. The ending definitely leaves room for a sequel, perhaps they have plans for free episodic content? If so, it would have been nice for them to leave a "To be continued" at the end of the credits.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								This review is obviously just about the current state of the game. Right now I think this game is highly overprized. Although the mechanics work well and I didn't encounter any bugs there is just not much to do. The so called "story mode" isn't worth it's name. There's just a tiny textblock before you are thrown into a mission. And that's pretty much all you do. Start a mission get some money to level up, grab some items and leave the building.  You repeat this until you die. You unlock new characters but right now there seem to be just 4 characters (2 of which you have right from the start).The design seems to be pretty nice but it's highly repetetive as well. Most buildings look pretty much alike, although the rooms are in a different order and stuff like that. I do think this game has potential. With a well made story, FAR more things to unlock than there are right now, and some new textures for buildings and stuff like that, this could be a fun game. But even after all that I think 20€ are quite alot to ask for this.

Posted: May 14, 2015
												I enjoyed the first two levels. After that it's just tortuously hard, achieved by simply throwing enemies at you until you fail.It doesn't matter how careful a spy you are, the game fakes a constantly rising threat level so even if you never put a foot wrong, the game will detect you every three or four moves and send another couple of fresh and increasingly well-armed troops to find you. It becomes not so much a game of sneaking, but a game of pathetically dancing around one square on the grid that for some reason no guard ever investigates, until the game decides to send three new guards to that exact spot.Not much fun.Only get this if you actively enjoy almost impossible challenges, even on 'Easy'.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												What looks to be an incredibly polished turn based action game is actually hampered by poor UI design and incredibly boring gameplay. Most of the gameplay consisted of just walking from room to room and passing your turn (to get more AP so you can walk to another room).I am a big fan of Klei's other games, and the animation and style is clearly polished, but the gameplay and UI are lacking. I had to refund this one.PROS:-Great art-Good voice acting-Lots of modes (level generation)-Multiple agents with different abilitiesNEUTRAL:-The "increasing alarm" system is misguided. I assume the purpose is to make exploration a risk/reward system, but this system (combined with the excessive walk/pass, see below) got on my nerves rather quickly.CONS:-Terrible UI design (NOT intuitive at all)-REALLY boring gameplay. The distances that must be covered are too long, so you will constantly be moving all of your agents, then ending the turn to get more AP, then moving them again, then ending the turn again....SO exciting. -Although different agents existed, their differences were not very clear by reading the stat screens (crappy UI), nor is anything really explained (even starting with the easiest mode). In my first 4 missions there were a number of instances where I had to stand on a particular tile to reveal the presence of a camera across the room, but there is no way to know that "this" is the tile to stand on ( as opposed to all the ones next to it).

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												Update: This game is unplayable in it's current version. The camera wants to pan to the middle of the map. I've tried everything, but I can't get the camera to stay centered on my agents, so I can't even start the tutorial. Reading the forums, other people have had this problem, with no clear solution. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------It has a very cool theme and the gameplay is clever. The early access version gives you the sense that there is a cool world to explore and ways to improve the characters. The only problem is that with no way to save, and very difficult missions, you have to keep re-starting. For example, learning that I needed armor piercing to kill a guard only occured only after the mission had started. With the guard blocking a key point, and no way to kill the guard, there was no way to progress in the mission and no way to go back to a previou save.  The end result is that you get the feeling that all the neat stuff is out of reach as you replay the first missions again and again.

content:

Early Access Review
								Don't get Early Access, wait until the bugs are fixed. The game is great, but intermittently causes rage-inducing total party kills with its bugs. This game isn't Bethesda-buggy, instead there are a few very precise bugs with gameplay. These bugs will get your team killed, on hour 60 of your playthrough, and the only mode of the game is Ironman, so no reloading.  Bugs like armour penetration upgrades not working on armoured enemies, guards shooting instantly instead of going to overwatch, and implants that don't proc when they say they will have all killed playthroughs.

number of helpful: 0 of 7 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												This is a game that was on my wishlist.  I enjoyed the introduction to the game and the backdrop.  That was about as much fun as I was going to have in the game.  Highly disappointed! :(The game is beautiful artwork and runs smoothly.  It opens and gives the player a basic tutorial on actions and abilities.But what really kills the fun is the inability to take all these high tech toys and abilities and do something useful.  When you start a level, you know only that your objective is somewhere in the game area and you have to search for it.  You can hack cameras, unlock safes, and disable drones that wander around.  You know what would be useful?A MAP OF WHERE THE OBJECTIVE IS LOCATION!That way, my operatives can move quickly to the location instead of fumbling around like keystone cops.  I know, sounds like an intelligent idea; to bad people in 2074 do not have those....Then there are the guards.  How they move about reminds me of "Commando: Behind Enemy Lines".  Unlike Commandos, my operatives have some sort of moral streak against killing guards.  Yes, they will not kill people, but steal their stuff and beat them up, that's OK.  The operatives start off as enemies of the state.  And the guards whom your up against are more than happy to kill youer operatives.Again, the game has many nice qualities.  But not  knowing where to go quickly nor neutralizing the guards enough not to be an issue later, is more aggrivating then fun.If Steam allowed for a 'maybe' option, I'd go for that.  If someone asked, I would explain things and help with what ever questions from my limited experience.  I just did not have fun with it.  Maybe it'll be fun for them!

number of helpful: 1 of 14 people (7%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
												Game is super overrated. It's cool in a lot of regards but the whole "it's a campaign, sort of, but your supposed to play it over and over again" is really lame IMO. It's not a survival game like don't starve.. It should be a tactical, stealth, story driven game. I was told this was Xcom, just rogue like. It's not at all. It's a mini game with very little substance.I don't really understand why it would be that much harder for Klei to make a real campaign, with slow story developments. Perhaps DLC?It just feels totally stupid to care about your characters or make meaningful decisions when the games ends like right after you start it.. Tetris you are supposed to play over and over, I get it.. But in Tetris you don't level up and make choices just to have them all start over again anyways the next time you play...

content:

												After playing this with the updates, I still cannot recommend this game.The stealth factor in this game is great and the use of each agents abilities to pull off a mission is also great.  There are still bugs in this game, one that ruined the last mission in the game for me.  I closed the door, silently, behind an enemy and he somehow knew it despite facing the other direction.This game does frown on killing enemies, so don't expect to pull off some stealth kills, just stuns.What hurts this game for me is the missions themselves.  I expect to be able to steal more items for use while in mission but I'm usually buying them during the mission.  Very rarely does Monst3r have anything to sell me in between missions.I'm certain this game will appeal to a lot of people but it is not my cup of tea.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Despite what pro-gamers may write here, I've struggled to get into this game. The graphics and the idea is rather nice. However, it is not very accessible - very little explanation of how something works and why it doesn't. Too often you are having to click repeatitively around the screen for something which works. You are a walking by objects which look like you ought to be able to interact with them but don't.Money is used both to level up your agents and to buy equipment - does that even make sense?? Equipment cannot be bought between missions, only during missions - so you go to a shop computer and instantly get your items during the mission?This is a complete RIP-OFF - I cannot believe such an underhatched, halfmade game is being sold at all. Will spend lots of my spare time making sure it gets as much bad PR through the net as possible. Do not buy this!

Posted: March 11
 DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine Invisible, Inc. is a game developed and published by Klei Entertainment, the same people behind Mark of the Ninja. Invisible, Inc. is simply one of the best single-player games I've ever playedThe theme is evoked well and the mechanisms of play are finely tuned. The real genius though, lies in how the game handles mistakes. In many games failure just costs time, or you are forced to reload whenever you make a mistakeInvisible, Inc. also allows this, but it really shines when you set up a game without rewinds or reloads. Then you get to experience how good a game can really beThe perfectly executed stealthy infiltration can quickly become a deadly game of cat and mouse, and successfully pulling unconscious agents out of a botched operation is way more satisfying than a reload could ever bePoints of reference could be XCOM or the best roguelikes, but I think Invisible, Inc. outclasses them allMy only criticism lies with how certain equipment can make core elements of the game trivial to overcome. It's not so fun when you have a "super agent" able to avoid or overcome all oppositionThe relatively short campaign time-frame and random item availability prevents this from becoming a significant problem though RECOMMENDED :)

content:
Posted: April 6
												Entertaining but a bit short. I particularly like the comic graphics. I finished it on Beginner in just about 13 hours. Not sure about replay value after knowing the game mechanics. It's a turn based stealth game. There is a couple different mission types to go through until you reach the final level. Each missions increases in difficulty with time. You need to run your agents through the mission to solve a particular quest and then flee the location. The levels can have side missions. Usually you will need about 30 to 60 minutes per mission, which roughly equals 15 to 30 turns. You gain money and items on the missions to improve your agents. Or you can go on rescue missions to find more agents. I don't think anything you do during a mission has any impact storywise. At least, I did not notice anything. I feel the game could have been more if the story had been, well, a story instead of just a loose bracket around the missions. Also, the characters are a lost opportunity for making the game more interesting if they somehow would impact on gameplay. But they are basically just the same statbags. Still a good game if you can get it for a bargain price.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								SECOND EDIT: The final game allows an excellent level of difficulty customization, from "filthy casual" to "brutal masochist." There's nothing really to add to the first edit I made apart from that. This game is amazing. Everything I hoped it would be when I saw the trailer and more. Without question the best early access game I've bought and the best game I've bought in 2015 so far. If you like tactical combat and a stealth based version of that sounds interesting you absolutely should get this game. You won't be disappointed. The developers seem to be actively working on it and I can see this becoming a classic like X-COM, it's that good.The emphasis is very much on the stealth/combat missions, with minimal rpg elements, but that works fine in this context, and endless mode means you'll get lots of hours of play out of it (I certainly have).STRONGLY RECOMMENDEDORIGINAL REVIEW: This is a rogue-like, a fact which is mentioned absolutely nowhere on the game's store page. Ignore every other tag or adjective in the description as they are completely secondary to relentless, punishing rogue-like heart of this game.On the surface I should love this game. Turn based tactical stealth? Count me in! And the basic mechanics are a lot of fun. The actual game side of it is really good, and I enjoyed it a lot. The graphics are really nice. If this were an X-COM style game I'd be giving this a thumbs up, because it has the potential to be an amazing amount of fun. Hell, it is an amazing amount of fun.But it's a rogue-like. A rogue-like with the difficulty turned up to eleven. And that's what takes all the fun out of this game and stamps on it until it's no fun at all. If you make a mistake, you get 1 do over/mission. Make 2 mistakes and you may as well delete your surviving agents and start over from the beginning. Not even joking. If you lose an agent, particularly after a few missions when you've spent some of your extremely scarce resources upgrading them, start over from the beginning. The mission difficulty ratchets steadily and if you've made any strategic mistakes with how you upgraded and equiped your agents, start over from the beginning. If you've even been a bit unlucky, didn't get the money or equipment you needed on the earlier levels because they didn't spawn, start over from the beginning. And that's the "Easy" difficulty level. I haven't even looked at "Normal."EDIT: OK, I figured out how to get infinite money and power with Cheat Engine[1]. Once the punishing difficulty level is taken out, OMG how much fun is this game! I've been playing endless mode for hours and it is so good. Slowly building up your agents' gear and augments, leaning how to deal with the different situations. With the difficulty tweaked and/or getting rid of the nosave, permadeath BS I could see this turning into a cult game like X-COM. I really want to give this game a positive review because it does so much right. I just can't while I need to use 3rd party hacking tools to make it something other than an exercise in misery and frustration. [1] They're stored as Doubles, and the memory address changes every mission, so you're going to have to either rescan every mission or do something clever with pointers if you want to cheat all the time.

												Satisfying, Ingenious, and challenging, Invisible inc is a great title. The game is always challenging you, the security is always risng, The drowns are hounding you and you dont have enough power to hack them, the lack of credits and equipment always hindering you, this game really puts the pressure on. If you play on begginer (which is very challenging) you get a couple redos for turns, other than that its cutthroat! If an agent dies, he's dead. If you screw up and get shot your done. This Game is really fun and addicting! It really makes you feel like a spy. P.S. Those Deamons really suck...

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												+Great visual style.+HARD gameplay but with plenty of forgiving attributes.+Customizable difficulty.+Great level generator that actually makes levels feel different.+Lots of class and personality.+Fun looting.+REWIND FUNCTION!-Cutscenes are dull (The 3D animation as opposed to 2D animation from earlier Klei games doesn't have the same charm or quality).-Augments don't really feel like they do anything in particular.-Non-story.-Agents don't appear to ever interact or say anything as opposed to other SRPGs like Disgea or Fire Emblem.Klei Entertainment did it again, providing a stylish and unconventional game complete with aweome in-game animationa nd gampelay. Invisible Inc. is the their second foray into the stealth genre, and like the first one, it's an exceptional must play; it even went so far as to turn stealth into a turn based game,and it actually works. Invisible Inc. essentially plays as a randomly generated puzzle, but not only are the "puzzles" cerebral and open to experimentation, but the random generation is absolutely rock-solid.The only major issue in terms of gameplay is that the thematically famous "augments" are entirely boring, and while do affect player ability, they don't really feel like they make a proper impact when compared to, say, Deus Ex: Human Evolution.

												I recommend this game to everyone who likes tactical turn base games. In this game you lead a team of agents on their revenge on corporations, you have to chose your tagets from few available missions and then complete objectives and run away with loot.There is also endless mode in which difficulty goes up and game will never end, unless you fail and all your agents die.While on mission you have to balance between stunning/killing guards or simply avoiding them. It is a nice tactical choice, killing is easy, but raises alarm level and reduces money gains from missions while stunning will require you to carry guard bodies and watch them not to wake up too early.On top of that you have to use AI at your disposal to hack objects like cameras, drones, safes and manage resource for hacking which is Power.There is first DLC for this game but I haven't tested it yet.I haven't seen any bugs, there are a lot of options to tweak difficulty level and plenty of game modes.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												Invisible, Inc. is a turn based strategy game set in a technologically advanced future. Players will control covert agents as they infiltrate high powered corporations to raid high security vaults, steal advanced technology, rescue captured operatives, and download important data.  Along the way the agents will face a myriad of threats like armored corporate security officers, drones, laser walls, and security turrets.Players take turns against the computer moving their agents through the randomly generated levels, doing their best to stay out of site while they hack security nodes through their cyberspace combat program, Incognito.  Depending on the programs you have loaded determines how you’ll bring down cameras, unlock electronic safes, and take control of camera drones. After each level you’ll spend credits on buying and selling equipment and leveling up your agents’ skills.Invisible, Inc. plays a lot like Xcom, which I personally love. It’s difficult to put down.  You’ll get so engrossed in completing a level you won’t realize time is passing! Difficulty ramps up at a reasonable pace so you never feel like you’re completely in control.  In fact some levels become downright tense!Each level has an objective and an exit zone.  You can leave any time you discover the exit, but you’ll want to try and complete your mission first.  There are several factors that make this difficult.  First, there’s a security meter that rises one point every turn.  Every five points raises the security level and will add complications like new guards on patrol, turning on more security cameras, and even pinpointing the location of one of your agents on the map and sending a guard to investigate.If that wasn’t enough, guards you knock out won’t stay that way forever.  And once they wake up, they will start searching the entire level for you.  Eventually you’ll have access to lethal weapons, but using these can raise the alarm level much faster as almost all security guards are equipped with heart monitors.  Games can get very tense as you try and steer the guards away from the exit so you can make your escape with the 3000 credits you just stole from the corporate vault!I enjoy how accessible the game is to first time players.  It’s not very difficult to learn and the beginner difficulty (which I recommend everyone play, regardless of your skill level with strategy games) explains all of the features in the game while being forgiving enough to not beat you over the head when you make a mistake.  At higher difficulty levels, the safety net drops away and you’ll find that every mistake can have dire consequences for your team.Overall, I find Invisible, Inc. to be fun and engaging.  The gameplay is challenging without being unfair. I particular enjoyed the art style, which has a retro feel about it.  After 15+ hours, I feel confident recommending this title to anyone looking for a new turn-based strategy experience.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 29, 2015
												   A game of simple concept & simple graphics, however, extremely well coded.Pros:   1) Utilise mere 5mins on first mission (tutorial) to understand how to play this game properly   2) Levelling / talent spec choice is entirely up to you to suit your gameplay preference (more stealth vs more action)   3) Maps are randomly generated with certain fixed parameter. Every game feels different and exciting especially towards Day 2, even more thrill when playing Iron man mode.   4) Weapons / Items / Augmentation. These are well balance in my opinion. You utilise all or focus more on 1 or more of these, again up  to personal preferences   5) Difficulty scales at a very appropriate rate. You will always feel challenged and proceed with cautious Cons:   1) Camera rotation feels weird at the begining. Some paths are not visible no matter and it can be cumbersome at times to keep rotating camera and using "Incognition view". After some getting used to, this is acceptable   2) Game play too short. Even with high re-playability, counting normal mode, endless mode, expert plus mode, this game is still short. You can complete the story once in normal mode within 4hrs. Having said that, this game is meant to be played multiple times. With each game play, progressively increase the difficulty and aiming towards clearing all achievements.   Conclusion: If you like turn based strategy game, this is one of the best. If you enjoyed XCom, this is the game you will also enjoy.

												This game scratches so many itches for me - it's a beautifully executed stealth game with rng-free tactics and a roguelite component that I've been missing dearly in recent games. This game is definitely not for everyone since the campaign is rather short and there's really not too much of a plot in here. You should pick this up if you like XCOM, roguelik(t)es or stealth games, and if you happen to like more than one of those at once - BUY THIS GAME RIGHT NOW!

I cannot wait for the DLC which expands the story and adds even more to the game.

												A wonderful combination of short-range tactical and long-range strategic concerns in a futuristic corporate spy setting. The turn-based approach seems plodding at first, but it allows for delicate precision in making every move count. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												Invisible Inc is a fantastic game. Graphics and voice acting are whimsical, yet elegant (the latter is rare in games). The game mechanics are so very well thought out. The missions are surprisingly un-repetitive, and have just the right lenght for a nice little session. There is not much of a story, but a good tension arch with a not too long campaign that gets progressively more difficult.What it somehow manage to do, is that I'm getting just barely through the missions, yet I manage them. This combination of just barely dodging the bullet and outsmarting the level gives a nice sense of achievement.That this happens so often, and so many, shows that it is not a coincidence, but rather a result of a couple of well designed game mechanisms. Moreover, this happens on procedurally designed maps, that could be unfair or easy just out of luck. Somehow the game gives you enough tools to compensate it. Rock paper shotgun analysed this, and found that the flexible structure of objectives and a risk level that increases with every turn are responsible. It is up to the player how much they chose to risk, and how much reward they get. Immediate mistakes are forgiven, due to a roll-back function. However, strategical mistakes can get one in a situation where roll-back does not suffice. Here one has to improvise, accept losses and recover, or get busted. Failure is part of the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												This is an incredible stealth-based tactics RPG. I frequently describe it to my friends as "the second best stealth game I've ever played." Why second best? Because Klei already made Mark of the Ninja.It features a surprisingly deep cast of playable characters that have just enough in their one-lines and informational bio's that they have subtlely real personalities. The maps are designed in a seemless procedural generation that always leaves a mission challenging but doable. The four stat mechanic (Speed, Strength, Hacking, and Anarchy) is simple enough to understand and extremely effective in execution. The variety of weapons, items, and implants for your agents and programs for your AI buddy Incognita offers a bunch of different playstyles. And the setting... that cyberpunk noir... mmm...

content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Post release update: This game is even better than I hoped it would be. It is a wonderful mix of Shadowrun Returns, Mark of the Ninja with just a hint of XCOM. The tension between trying to get everything and the ever-increasing security level is perfect, and the difficulty level customisation options are brilliant. A+ gameOriginal Early Access review: Invisible, Inc is a fantastic turn-based stealth strategy game. The gameplay is spot on and really, really tense. Violence really is not a good option which I love (it just makes more trouble for you!) and the game is all the better for it. As could be expected given Mark of the Ninja they show real confidence in the stealth mechanics, but stealth here is about precise placement and tactical thought, rather than in darkness and movement. Both are brilliant. Finely tuned, beautiful to look at, with lovely music this could be a finished game already.Klei are doing Early Access right with this game. I bought the game when it was pre-Early Access and development has been a joy to watch as Klei are working hard to craft a gem of a game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												Invisible Inc. What is there to say about it?Hm, well, that's the question.Invisible Inc is often described as roguelike, or in the words of TotalBiscuit "Rogue-Lite". Unless you're playing on a custom difficulty to unwind, expect to die A LOT.Let's break this down, then.Story;Invisible Inc has an incredibly short story, but still a fun one to watch, with 2 very nicely animated cutscenes that to me at least felt reminiscent of The Incredibles. Its cast of characters are fairly fun, for what we get to learn of them. Central in particular has to be the best in the game - not only does she have the best voice, but you also feel for her plight and genuinely feel scolded for letting agents die.Gameplay:Being a turn-based stealth strategy game, things will go wrong, a LOT. Often resulting in death. Fortunately there is a "rewind" option which allows you to go back to the beginning of the previous turn. Of course, while this is useful, barring custom mode, your Rewinds are limited and you may have made a mistake much earlier that caused your problems now.the stealth gameplay is really enjoyable and the combat is simple, and just a little frustrating if you don't have the ability to knock out your enemy before they shoot you, or if you are surrounded. I would criticise how hard it is to obtain enough money to keep your equipment up to date with the difficulty increase each in-game "day". You'll very quickly find yourself surrounded by armoured guards without armour-piercing weapons while trying to get an extra agent in a detention centre, and that certainly doesn't feel nice.Similarly, there is a "hacking" feature to change the sides of security features in the levels such as drones and cameras. This is absolutely vital for you to maintain a stealthy approach. However, in an endless mode, even on super-easy difficulty settings, Daemons (programs that activate upon hacking, none of which have positive effects) will begin spawning automatically at the beginning of the level, including one which adds a Daemon into ALL hackable items in the level, severely limiting your ability to do, well, anything.I do applaud it for punishing killing, however. Though despite this, there have been too many situations where killing EVERYONE is the only way to survive a level. Also, while the levels are randomly generated, this isn't necessarily a good thing. While it improves replay value, there have been too many situations where the only way to advance is to go through a room with a stationary guard who is watching the only door you can go through, meaning you will have to risk increasing security by killing or KOing him. Bonus negatives if said guard is more armoured than you have the ability to deal with at the time.Modding:Currently, there is too little in the modding scene for this game. I would really like to see some modding support for agent creation, items and missions in the future. Right now the only real mods are language packs, which is nice if you speak a different language but that's not really a mod otherwise. TL;DR: Great gameplay, nice short story, needs more modding.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
												"Invisible, Inc" is the best designed and most polished game I have played in a long time. The balance between all the different items, augments, and options in general is just perfect. Almost every single level unfolds into an epic mission, where every AP counts, and I somehow (it baffles myself!) manage to barely escape in the end. When I lose, which happens often, it is always because of a mistake or miscalculation on my own side. The game isnt unfair. It isnt frustrating. It is challenging in the best way possible, where it's up to YOU if you fail or succeed, and to do creative kiting or maneuvres to escape in one piece. I have bought so many games lately, from indies to AAA, and none of them have been as fun and addicting as Invisible, Inc.I can only recommend! :)

												This game is close to perfect.  I don't understand how they've managed to get the mechanics so tight; the escalating threat, the close shaves, the number of missions where you feel you've only just escaped, the number of missions where you have to choose to leave a team member or key objective behind or risk all-out failure.  It's just so damn good.  So many games try to pull it off and so few succeed so beautifully.I could write about this for a really long time.  Short story:  the art, sound and story are great, but it's that amazing, amazing gameplay that makes this one of my favourite games ever.

												I'm a fan of roguelike and strategy games, and this game does an especially good job with its gameplay.The game features randomized levels, enemies, items, and other game elements.  Normally, after I play through similar games, I think of ways to the randomness could be changed to improve the game, but Invisible Inc balances the random elements so well that I'd rather they not change it.The gameplay overall is fun and addictive.  The main improvements I'd have liked would be a nicer user interface and an easier way to skip dialogue that I've already seen dozens of times.  With that being said, I highly recommend this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												Invisible Inc. is a meticulously clockwork strategy game. The only uncertainty here, is information you do not yet have, and AI decisions. Yet, even in these areas the game gives you extensive information to play with. You can see at a glance exactly which of the areas you can see, are also observed by guards. You know enemy health and traits. Even the destination and object of a guard's interest may be divined. This is very empowering, and puts most failures squarely on the player.At first, you'll want to avoid ever being seen. Soon, you'll be satisfied with escape when spotted. Eventually, you'll confidently pull the strings of the enemy to send them hither and yon, as you scamper about your business. It's an awesome feeling when you pull it off.I love the slick sci-fi setting; the characterizations are nice and refreshingly diverse. Unit upgrades are fun, and the stage dressing is nicely on theme. The worst I can say is that like all roguelikes, you must first learn the game before you can win at it. Also, you're going to rely on a bit of luck to have the options that you want. Overall, the limited "rewind" system is a good way to offer a safety net, although I do miss that tool on the higher difficulty settings.The best I can say is, I loved the challenge and was glad to be able to complete it. The unlocks on failure were a great way to spin straw into gold. I liked the expansion, but that difficulty really gets up there. This is a good game to play if you enjoyed X-Com, FTL, Dungeons of Dredmor or Mark of the Ninja. The fusion of stealth and turn based strategy is, in the context of a roguelike, exquisite.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												While this game is fun to play, it's ridiculously difficult even on the beginner setting. If you like turn based strategy games you'll enjoy it, but getting out alive is an extremely difficult task. It takes a full playthrough of the game (about 3 hours) to even begin to understand what you are doing. This game is challenging, but sometimes it seems unfair. The procedural generator can be very unforgiving, throwing you into a difficult map including many rooms where the objective and exit are on wildly different parts of the map, forcing you to traverse back through the mess of guards that just woke up. The game world is already set up for you to lose. Because the maps are procedurally generated, you can get maps that literally are not possible to beat without sacrificing a large portion of your team.Unless you might like a very challenging spatial strategy game, I'd save your money until they deal with the difficulty.This is all on Beginner mode. Each approach you take has HUGE consequences down the line and the game's alert level system just brings the crushing weight of time down on you. The cost and armor level of the guards go up very quickly without providing much to help you in return.The game feels polished, but they've got a lot to do difficulty wise. I'm still coming back to the game, but my first playthrough I didn't complete any objectives because of the level of difficulty. If the DEV wants the players to play perfectly, they should make it a bit easier on beginner mode.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												Another fine game from Klei to say the least. Had this since April of last year and I'm very pleased as to how the final product turned out. Yet another fresh take on stealth by Klei, this is a turn based tactical espionage game that features procedurally generated levels and permadeath(though there are mission retries on the lowest difficuly). It may not explicitly state this, but it is very much structured like a modern rougelike (a la FTL) with playthroughs lasting around the ballpark of a couple hours and a lot of variation between each playthrough. You create a team whenever you start a playthrough, selecting any two of ten unlockable agents(six of which have an alt form so technically 16) and two mainframe programs. There is a hacking element in the game that features resource management of CPU power that can be used to hack various devices such as cameras, safes, etc. There's also an alarm level that ticks every turn, Forcing a lot of different decisions(do I go after that nanofabricator machine and buy some gear or escape before things get too hectic?) and making the gameplay more dynamic. Overall, I love the gameplay of this game. Not many games can keep me playing for 70 hours(and I don't plan on stopping now) but Invisible Inc has enough depth and variation to keep me playing. Also, as with every game Klei makes, the artstyle of this game is wonderful. My only complaint I have is that the couple of cinematics they put in the game very recently could have been better quality. Voice acting is a little flat and it looks a little grainy. Overall I definately recommend this game.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												TLDR: turn-based tactical espionage action in a stilish cyberpunk setting. You will learn the importance of closing doors!In this future cyberpunk setting, you are cast as an operator trying to survive a hunt called by many corporations, hoping to last 72 hours so that you can strike back (there are custom and endless modes available too).In the strategic map, you will choose where to deploy your team between the different randomly generated mission available, each offering different objectives, enemies and rewards. Once chosen, you will proceed to a turn-based, XCOM like mission. Unlike XCOM, sneaking and not engaging the enemy is the order of they day.Despite lacking an enfasis on combat, each mission is a tense and tight affair where you are using all the tools available. The wonderful and atmosferic soundtrack enhances the gameplay.I have enjoyed this game so far, my only negative is that some of the mechanics are not covered by the tutorial or in the help section, so you will have to do some googling to find your answers.

The main improvements I'd have liked would be a nicer user interface and an easier way to skip dialogue that I've already seen dozens of times.  With that being said, I highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												This game is absolutely fantastic and is the most addictive game I've played since FTL. I'm not even into stealth games but everything about this game, from the gameplay, graphic style, music and sound effects all come together to build a tense, edge of your seat experience.I've had so many close call heroic victories in this game and also heart breaking defeats. Highlights include having my agent surrounded by guards and using a cloak modded with an electric burst, knocking them all out. Another time on the final mission a critical character was shot by guards but I was able to purchase a med gel and revive him, all the while Shalem shot dead several of the guards. Overall it's hard to explain what's so good, it's just worth playing.Only negatives for me are as follows:- don't play on beginner difficulty it's far too easy with 5 rewinds per level- it's too easy to unlock all agents and programs! Would like to have been made to work harder.- it took me a while to get used to the action point system including the fact that opening/closing doors doesn't cost any points. It seems a bit strange and there's rarely a good reason to leave a door open. It breaks the flow of the game a bit having to close them all the time and annoying when you forget to.Overall please bring on the DLC I'll happily lap it up!!

												Slightly recommended.This game is turn-based and about stealth, and about break-ins to support your struggle against different companies, break-ins you do at those companies. the options available differ somewhat though, and maps seem to be generated for each run, so there's no risk running into the same map twice, not at least from what I've experienced.The agents at your disposal differ some at the beginning, upgrades (augmentations) can make them differ alot though, upgrading their skill can make them more similar if that's your choice, or make them even more specialized, should you wish for that.While playing, you have 2-4 agents, depending on earlier missions, to execute your objectives, and to help you you have some sort of AI that allows you to hack different terminals, safes etc. The game plays out really well in my opinion, and the only issue actually is the amount of missions. You should know before purchasing this game that the campaign isn't more than 7 missions or so, wich might seem a bit short.Replayability lies in playing different difficulty modes, and of course playing the different difficulties in iron man mode as well. There's also other modes in general, as some type of time trial. Although, if you're picking this up for playing the campaign, waiting for a sale might be recommended. Somewhat overpriced considering that.If you, on the other hand, won't be bothered by exploring the different difficulty levels as the way to get your game time in this game, then by all means, pick it up full price. I do however think that even for those players, waiting for a sale is a good move.

												Presentation: +- nice art style, animations, good visual feedback on important game elementsGameplay: + - Invisible Inc.'s core gameplay, sneaking a small party of agents through technology- and guard-wise protected facilities, is executed really well and all given game subsystems work well together- selectable difficulty options enable a customized challenge- thanks to procedurally generated levels, no playthrough is the same ...Gameplay: -- ... number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								I loved Mark of the Ninja. Klei proved without question they can do stealth gameplay well, and I grabbed this game on the strength of that alone.Be aware that the game is rough around the edges, and you're going to die a lot before you even understand how to play properly. It's difficult to tell where rooms actually begin and end in some cases, and where line-of-sight is. Some elements of the background are easily mistaken for rooms you don't currently have LOS to. Also, when planning where you're going to move to next, it's hard to tell where you can be spotted from that position.It's not clear whether an edge is a wall or a corridor you haven't been down yet. Considering that every move counts, you can't waste time exploring a wall that you thought was actually a pathway.That said, you can rotate the view left and right with Q and E, which alleviates this problem somewhat.It's not obvious when enemies are going to regain consciousness. It's two turns from when you knock them out. I'm not even sure whether than means they revive on turn two or on turn three.It's not obvious at ALL where reinforcement enemies are going to spawn from, and it badly needs to be. More than once I've sneaked into the enemy spawn room accidentally, a guard has spawned the next turn and killed me.Basically, it's difficult to get to grips with how the game actually works, so it's going to take some perserverence.On the plus side, the game is very hard :) . It has the feel of a roguelike, where your own skill and experience makes the difference between success and failure. Also, it has permadeath.Previously I'd complained that you unlock more abilities and whatnot purely from grinding. I was wrong. The unlocks are really just alternate stuff you can use, rather than things that are objectively better.Very difficult, very tense, and there's a lot of potential here that needs a bit more polish. On the balance, though, it's probably worth getting.

								Wow! It was very frustrating at first since my agents kept getting overwhelmed. The key is to ace the prisoner rescue missions as soon as possible which will add the rescued agents to your team, making later missions much more survivable. I think that the exit elevator should be made visible on the map when you first start so that you have a clear goal. Either that, or make it possible to exit without saving so you can bail out of a disaster without losing all your progress on that level. FYI for new players: If you are obviously losing, choose the 'retire' option at the bottom of the list on the pause menu. Your progress up to that point will accumulate as experience that will unlock more stuff.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								I think this is my game of 2014, because it is so dang cohesive. The art is full of personality, the staff team is dedicated to interacting with their forums, and the game design is focused on creating the highest number of risk-reward decisions. This kind of game may be frustrating for beginners because it has a high difficulty curve, but that's actually the enjoyable part of this game. When a pattern of recurring situations has led to your failure, it is also an opportunity to create a deep satisfaction when you've figured out your own strategy and methods of response. I'm looking forward to see how this game further develops as it's currently at early-access. I highly recommend it for anyone who loves strategy turn-based games and is willing to accept that it takes many fails to figure out how to play the game well.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is in early access, so I'm allowed to be as critical as I like, right?Simply put, the game still has a few techincal issues left, I've had charaters fail to tazer an enemy next to them, while they were on overwatch for example. The bigger issue, however, is that the game's tutorial doesn't do a good enough job to explain the game's mechanics. There is a fine line between information given to the player, and information the player can find out for him/herself in a roguelike. I've died twice because of a poor tooltip on the cloaking device:-Running right in front of a guard while cloaked caused a guard to see me and kill me, I had no way of knowing it would do that, since you can pass through his visibility in any other point without being noticed.-Stealing from guards cancelled my cloak. I also had to watch a youtube video to know that pinning people legthens their KO-status (A VERY vital mechanic)Those are the mistakes I've made, but I've seen Youtubers mess up much worse because they simply had no info about some of the basic mechanics, or that they understood them wrong.I'm also left wondering about the character balance, since Internationale seems a bit underpowered compared to her peers at the moment (Banks is really good, but she's unlockable so I guess it's fine)Hm, what I thought of the game? It's right up my alley. I love strategy games in the vein of Xcom and Fire emblem, and I can see this as a roguelike that finally clicks for me. Can't wait for more story content.

Well done!EDIT:After more playtesting, I'd say the single biggest, and at the same time simplest, modification the devs could make is to make it possible for the agents to re-lock security doors once they have a passcard.A couple things I'd like to see: Some method whereby you can recover the gear you've previously lost in the field.An optional 'Casual' mode which doesn't affect your score, but in which permadeath doesn't happen.

												I don't play many stealth games (Mostly because I'm not all that great with them) but Invisible, Inc. Hits a high note for me that none of the other stealth games could. Klei in general have made some pretty amazing games, and I think this is just another example of their talent. Random level generation may be something that certain people may dislike, but I appreciate the rogue-like elements in play here and overall I think it suits the type of game it is. I also really enjoy the sense of progression that you have with the unlocks and so forth. I think it adds a nice little dimension to the game and gives it replay value. Final thing I'd like to say is that I extremely enjoy the campaign set up, and how you can customize the campaign to how easy/difficult you'd like it to be. Overall, I think its worth a look at even for people that aren't too keen on stealth games to begin with. I think you'll be pleasantly surprised.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
												First things first: This game is great. It's made by Klei. They rock. Buy it.Invisible Inc. is a turn-based stealth game similar to xcom or shadowfall, but with less emphasis on rpg elements and more on steath. The game is a joy to play and has no rng, like xcom, making the game entirely based on strategy. The game IS DIFFICULT for newcomers and it took me 2 semi-playthroughs and watching guides to be able to complete the game on beginner, before moving on to advanced. The characters are unque (although there should be more), the story is solid, the graphics look great, and the future theme is spot-on. I will say that the enimies aren't very unique, they usually only differ by appearance, or minor things like extra armor. Also, there should be more types of missions, and more layouts for the locations to make each playthough feel different. All in all, an enjoyable turn-based stealth that I plan on continuing for a while.Overview:Gameplay: 10/10Characters: 9/10Story: 8/10Music: 7/10Replayablility: 9/10FINAL SCORE: 9/10

content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												Solid fun, puzzle to solve that is able to keep it fairly fresh with randomly generated maps and enough options to tweak just how hard a fight you want to deal with. Unique (to me) combination of turn based play for a sneaker like this refreshing. Always enjoyed the Thief titles, but this is much more of a spy squad based setup with you as the "operator". Hacking angle with Incognita is a fun overlay on top of several other unique additions, that I won't spoil here. Great deal on sale at $12, I'd say worth the $20 as well if you think this may appeal to you as well. And for the real crazy folks that want the hardest challenge, go Ironman (perma-death) with a 2 minute time limit per turn. I enjoy the optimizing of every move that i plan out and taking my time. Once that gets old to me, I might try some speed runs and go full lethal attacks. Oh, and a bonus for me is the ability to save the game at any time and pick it right back up. Life gets in the way some times, this is just like pausing a chess game that is by far more fun.

												"Invisible, Inc" is the best designed and most polished game I have played in a long time. The balance between all the different items, augments, and options in general is just perfect. I have bought so many games lately, from indies to AAA, and none of them have been as fun and addicting as Invisible, Inc.I can only recommend! :)

												TLDR: turn-based tactical espionage action in a stilish cyberpunk setting. You will learn the importance of closing doors!In this future cyberpunk setting, you are cast as an operator trying to survive a hunt called by many corporations, hoping to last 72 hours so that you can strike back (there are custom and endless modes available too).In the strategic map, you will choose where to deploy your team between the different randomly generated mission available, each offering different objectives, enemies and rewards. Once chosen, you will proceed to a turn-based, XCOM like mission. Unlike XCOM, sneaking and not engaging the enemy is the order of they day.Despite lacking an enfasis on combat, each mission is a tense and tight affair where you are using all the tools available. The wonderful and atmosferic soundtrack enhances the gameplay.I have enjoyed this game so far, my only negative is that some of the mechanics are not covered by the tutorial or in the help section, so you will have to do some googling to find your answers.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												Another fine game from Klei to say the least. Had this since April of last year and I'm very pleased as to how the final product turned out. Yet another fresh take on stealth by Klei, this is a turn based tactical espionage game that features procedurally generated levels and permadeath(though there are mission retries on the lowest difficuly). It may not explicitly state this, but it is very much structured like a modern rougelike (a la FTL) with playthroughs lasting around the ballpark of a couple hours and a lot of variation between each playthrough. You create a team whenever you start a playthrough, selecting any two of ten unlockable agents(six of which have an alt form so technically 16) and two mainframe programs. There is a hacking element in the game that features resource management of CPU power that can be used to hack various devices such as cameras, safes, etc. There's also an alarm level that ticks every turn, Forcing a lot of different decisions(do I go after that nanofabricator machine and buy some gear or escape before things get too hectic?) and making the gameplay more dynamic. Overall, I love the gameplay of this game. Not many games can keep me playing for 70 hours(and I don't plan on stopping now) but Invisible Inc has enough depth and variation to keep me playing. Also, as with every game Klei makes, the artstyle of this game is wonderful. My only complaint I have is that the couple of cinematics they put in the game very recently could have been better quality. Voice acting is a little flat and it looks a little grainy. Overall I definately recommend this game.
