number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Invisible Inc. is a difficult Turn-Based Strategy Stealth game set in a world of mega corperations. You play in short campaigns of a handful of levels made with randomly procedurely generated rooms. The goal is gaining enough money through the use of stealing artifacts, dosh or valuable data from a VIP's brain to upgrade your team of agents after the initial collapse of Invisible.I like to think of this game as a blend of FTL: Faster Than Light, XCOM and Mark of the Ninja (a previous game developed and plublished by Klei Entertainment). Each playthrough can be completed in 1-2 sittings and the difficulty of the game makes each run a stressful but fulfilling exercise for stategy minded players.Every turn each of the agents in play are given action points (derived from the stats of the agent; upgradable with money) to perform moves, actions with items equipped and interactions with the environment across an isometric playing field. These environmental objects must first be hacked primarily with the Incognita system, a re-purposed A.I that can break down firewalls with the spending of power which can be replenished via consoles (as you progress, items and agent abilities can also accomplish this).There are layers of stategy with the cast of agents, the spread of item variety and the different programs to equip Incognita that make this short game replayable in alternate playstyles (hidden, sneaky with tazers, tazers and sleep syringes, full-on assault with firearms etc.) This stylish gem of a game deserves to be played by more people and the developers should be proud of how polished this Early Access game turned out.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
												Better than XCOM! Invisible Inc is my favorite game in my 100+ title Steam library!This game took me over 100 hours to beat expert-plus mode but it was worth it! The game takes 4-5 hours for a play through and the levels are procedurely generated. There are a wealth of unique agents, programs, and rewards so every play through really is different.There is a steep learning curve- you will die a lot. This is the point and this is how you learn, don't despair! It's important to balance patience with aggressive exploration. It's ok to usually play it safe, especially in higher difficulties! Here are some hints (or rather basic mechanics that you shouldn't overlook):1. Always peak or open a door before running into a new room.2. If you peak into a room with the door already open, the whole room is visible (good for corner cameras).3. Only hack what you need to for your current situation, conserve power when possible.4. Don't kill or KO gaurds if you can help it. Let them walk in the same predictable patterns as long as possible.5. Run when enemies won't be able to hear you (within 5 paces?).6. Upgrade agents to Anarchy level 1 then steal credits and passcards without KO'ing guards.7. If you screwed up and are going to use a rewind on this or the next turn, have other agents sprint to scout the map.8. Use Alt to see a guard's vision lines. You can run in the diagonal red shaded squares to distract them.Hope this helps. Make Invisible Inc 2, Klei!!!!

content:
Posted: June 3, 2016
												I love turn based strategy games and I also love stealth games. But only in my wildest dreamsI ever thought it could be possible to put together both of these styles of games in a single one. Invisible, Inc. turns that dream into reality and does it masterfully. The game mechanics are flawless; the playable characters feature distinct skills, enough to ensure different gameplay experiences depending on how you build and upgrade your team; And, as if it were not enough, also offers us an entertaining story to follow.The gradual increase system of difficulty levels, depending on how long it take to finish a stage, prevents the player to make reckless decisions. Every action here, no matter how small, carries an urgency weight that makes it much more exciting and fun the whole experience (and sometimes frustrating, I can't deny).The game's campaign is short, which is quite good as it prevents the experience to become repetitive for players less junkies in stealth or turn-based strategy. However, for the diehard fans of the both genres, Invisible is extremely replayable for two main reasons: every play the maps are randomly generated and the different characters to release every match ensures that the game remains fresh for a long time.--------------------------------------------------------Eu adoro jogos de estratégia em turnos e jogos de açõa furtiva. Mas nem nos meus sonhos mais malucos imaginei que veria esses dois estilos de jogo reunidos num só. Invisível, Inc. transformou esse sonho em realidade e o fez com maestria. A mecânica é impecável; os personagens possuem habilidades distintas o suficiente para garantir diferentes experiências de jogo dependendo de como se construi e atualiza a equipe; e, como se não bastasse, ele também oferece uma divertida história para acompanhar.O sistema de aumento gradual dos níveis de dificuldade, dependendo de quanto tempo se leve para concluir um estágio, impede que o jogador tome decisões imprudentes. Toda ação aqui, não importa quão pequena, carrega um peso de urgência que o torna tudo muito mais emocionante (e às vezes frustrante, não posso negar).A campanha do jogo é curta, o que é muito bom, uma vez que impede que se torne repetitivo para os jogadores menos viciados em estratégia baseada em turnos ou  ação furtiva. No entanto, para os fãs incondicionais de ambos os gêneros, Invisible é extremamente rejogável por duas razões principais: a cada jogada os mapas são gerados aleatoriamente e os diferentes personagens para serem liberados a cada jogo garantem que ele permaneça divertido por um longo tempo.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												In a nutshell: This game is kinda like Chess... but with cool gadgets.Lots of options to customise the gameplay to suit you, loads to unlock, pleasing visuals, potentially VERY challenging gameplay thanks to Endless mode... it's a great little package - smart, and well presented.I hope Invisible Inc. returns for a second outing.Review:I came across this game as a result of looking for a decent hacker/spy title. I got a tip from somebody in a comments section on a blog so I put it in my wishlist and finally made the investment during a sale.As I play on what I guess would now be considered an outdated laptop, I was concerned that it wouldn't run that well and there'd be lots of lag and slow-down, but it plays fine actually. And I'm happy that it does, because it's a quality game, especially so considering its sale price.- As mentioned earlier, this game is kinda like Chess in that it's a turn based game - you make your move, then the opponent makes theirs, and so on... what makes it interesting, apart from all the cool gadgets and the Random Number God (more on that later) is the ever-increasing incremental alarm system, meaning that not only do you feel somewhat under pressure, but also that each turn is precious, so thinking things through before you execute is advisable if you want to avoid coming into contact with some of the better equipped enemy personnel who lurk at the higher levels. Thankfully, there are no limits to how much time you spend during each turn (unless you select this option) so you get to consider things before ending your turn.- There are lots of things to unlock (including Augments, Programs, Weapons and Items, as well as new Characters), and a few different strategies based on what equipment loadout is selected, but it's essentially a stealth game, meaning there are few rewards (but plenty of penalties, mind) for a playstyle which is geared towards being overtly offensive.- The top-down, isometric view can at times present some frustrations, but only occasionally (when trying to view a narrow passageway, for example), and is quite pleasing overall.- On the subject of views - the cell shaded art style is easy on the eye, and whilst the in-game graphics are polished, functional and without flaw (from my experience, at least), some might consider them to be lacking when compared to the realism presented in other titles nowadays, not that this is a criticism of mine as I'm grateful that my old laptop can handle the visuals comfortably enough to allow for a smooth gaming experience. Let's call the graphics 'accessible' then.- Game length is very short if you're talking about completing just one single campaign, but the replay factor is ever-present thanks to rolling XP (used to unlock those unlockables mentioned earlier) and also what seems like a Random Number Generator (RNG) type of level generator - no two levels are the same, even if you have the restart option checked. This is clever and means there is no 'practice makes perfect' approach to the gameplay in any given level, as you always need to investigate and explore in order to locate the mission objective and exfiltration point which can lead to wrong decisions being made, and this is what makes it fun..... and also why you might want to have the NOOOOOOO! button to hand, as I wish I did when I realised I left my newly purchased (and expensive) Portable Server at the other side of the level, not realising I'd need to pick it up again before I snuck away into the night - ugh... There are, however, options to customise the gameplay, meaning you can choose the number of Rewinds etc to make the game harder or easier, depending on how you feel that day - this I like.- The voice acting is well done, but due to the short span of any given campaign, there isn't much of it. Quality over quantity.I actually wish the campaigns were longer, at least in terms of the story (which hints at the cliche outcome now and again), but having said that, there is a DLC option which promises to extend the campaign mode and offers more unlocks and challenges. So I look forward to playing this as well.Recommended :)

												This game is incredible. An interesting turn-based stealth game with a fair amount of content, a good soundtrack, and distinct artstyle are present but what really sets Invisible Inc. apart is the difficulty. When you start the game for the first time, the game advises you to start with beginner difficulty, and rightly so. I struggled to beat the campaign on the easiest difficulty on my first run, which never happens. However, what Invisible Inc. does best is pushing you to think several steps ahead everytime you play. Even when you've got four, well-upgraded agents towards the later stages of the game, if you mess up one move you get **** on. Combine that with randomly generated levels and you've got possibly the best stealth game ever made. Fantastic job Devs, will be looking for more where this came from. 9/10P.S. Try not to use Internationale (good luck) >.<

												Good game for fans of stealth, random level generation, turn based team combat. The default game settings (enemy difficulty, starting cash, stun/KO duration, etc.) can be a bit tricky for first time players but there are options to customise all of these and turn the game into something more manageable (or even harder if you want a challenge).The options also allow you to extend/reduce the fixed duration of the game or to turn it into an "endless" game ... it's not really endless, the enemies just get harder and harder and eventually you fail to complete too many missions or your team is all captured/killed. Ther random nature of the missions, equipment you can find/buy and the abilities you can find for your pet AI can make some of the games harder/trickier than other sessions but overall it is enjoyable. The game is not very long but it is one you will repaly again and again as you unlock new agents to play with.TLDR; nice game, no twitch responses needed, nice depth of strategy in all aspects of the game. Good value for money.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2015
												This game is a fairly unique take on the Turn Based Strategy genre. I highly recommend it to anyone that likes games like XCOM or Fire Emblem. The twist on this game compared to others in the genre is that its stealth based- instead of fighting the enemies head on, you want to try your best to avoid them. Your directly offensive options are fairly limited and you generally want to use them only in emergencies, because ammo is scarce and the enemies vastly outnumber you. That isn't to say that your options overall are limited, however. There are ways of fighting back that don't involve shooting someone with a gun in an open firefight. Setting silent ambushes and traps. Hacking the enemies security system and creating a false alert somewhere else in the building to redirect them. Turning a turret on their side to yours, evening the firepower some in a pinch.Invisible Inc is all about doing things the 'non standard' way for games of this genre, while still encapsulating what makes them great- plenty of ways to force you to think "How do I get out of this situation with what I have right now?", which leads to those satisfying moments when you pull off a clutch escape out of a bad situation, or the despair as you lose your best unit and need to find a way to salvage the game.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												I have been a fan of this game since paying for it in Early Access. Klei did a fantastic job with their other titles (Mark of the Ninja is a personal favorite of mine) and this is another solid piece of work. The game feels very much like an advanced kind of chess while you're playing it. The fact that your agents will die if spotted and not moved immediately makes the movements feel like a complex series of steps to avoid being in "check", so to speak.The addition of voice-acting and some cutscenes has fleshed out the story and compliments the music nicely. The story is nothing to write home about, but moves the game along and gives you some motivation on why things are the way they are in the game.Be warned: this is a difficult game that has a steep learning curve. You will fail. Many times. But every failure gets you further along and gets you more agents, new toys, and new ways to play the game.Highly recommend.

Early Access Review
								Post release update: This game is even better than I hoped it would be. It is a wonderful mix of Shadowrun Returns, Mark of the Ninja with just a hint of XCOM. The tension between trying to get everything and the ever-increasing security level is perfect, and the difficulty level customisation options are brilliant. A+ gameOriginal Early Access review: Invisible, Inc is a fantastic turn-based stealth strategy game. The gameplay is spot on and really, really tense. Violence really is not a good option which I love (it just makes more trouble for you!) and the game is all the better for it. As could be expected given Mark of the Ninja they show real confidence in the stealth mechanics, but stealth here is about precise placement and tactical thought, rather than in darkness and movement. Both are brilliant. Finely tuned, beautiful to look at, with lovely music this could be a finished game already.Klei are doing Early Access right with this game. I bought the game when it was pre-Early Access and development has been a joy to watch as Klei are working hard to craft a gem of a game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 14, 2016
												An excellent stealth centered, turn based roguelike game where each choice matters. The game does not joke about you having odds stacked against you in a direct firefight, instead you must use sneaky tactics to get around complex you infiltrated, get the objective and get out ASAP. Truly managed to captivate the hit and run tactic used by small agencies.However, speed as well as being undetected is the key. You will not remain undeteced forever as the security level increases over time, moreso if you are caught. Invisible Inc strikes a nice balance between having to be fast and stealthy, a quality that gives a healthy gameYour squad is also accompanied by a powerful AI, that playes a major role in your success by being able to manipulate facility devices to serve you instead but beware, they are protected and sometimes you need to think about your resource allocationI also highly recommend getting the DLC, contigeancy plan. It adds a bunch of items and characters to make the game more varied, opening up even more strategies and interesting synergies. It's only 4€ if bought in a bundle and well worth the small priceThe downside of this game however is  that if you are not familiar with stealth or strategy games, then Invisible inc can be quite difficult to pick up and learn as the tutorial is quite honestly lacking finer important details which you will discover as you play. Thus I recommend starting up from the easiest difficulty (it still provides a decent challenge) and move up until you hit the hardest difficulties, which is what the game balance is centered around and what defines the true invisible inc experienceAs a final word: Try to save knockouts and kills until the last moment where you absolutely need to do so and use the corpse drag option to prevent guards from waking up

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
												EDIT a year and 400 hours later:I cannot recommend this game enough, it is a must buy. It's one of those games where it's incredibly challenging and most of your losses are due to poor planning and unthought actions. Stealth is key as much as avoiding violence.If you avoid violence, this game is a lot easier for you. And that's all you can hope for considering how difficult the game gets later on when guards have armor and mainframes become even harder to hack through.It's been an emotional experience for me mastering this game, here's a link to my blog post about it that the developers appreciated a lot: https://yourwritetolive.com/2016/08/22/what-i-learned-from-being-a-spy/Otherwise, here's my original review below:40 hours in and I STILL haven't beaten Experienced Mode, but I love this game to death! I've had it for maybe a week or two by now, beaten Beginner, and my own customized version of Experienced Mode with level retries, and I can't get enough of it. The gameplay mechanics are top notch. It is a turn based, top view, stealth game where you need to be very careful how you spend your Action Points and Hacking PWR. As you progress through the campaign, you can earn a ton of skills and items that help you aide in your missions.It can range from having armor piercing weapons to take down the stronger guards, to also getting better hacking programs from Incognita so that you can better sneak around corporation headquarters. The mission types have a great variety: you can find Cybernetic Labs to enhance your team's abilities, recon powerful items, or simply loot heavily guarded vaults for credits that you can use to buy skill points or other items. Even better is the Financial Suite type of missions where you can find corporate executives and steal vault access cards from them for even greater rewards in said mission types.What I don't like about this game is how short the campaign is. You only get 72 game hours to get to the final mission, and basically when you send your team to a mission, each location has different amount of hours it takes to fly there, so you gotta be careful.You can always increase the amount of hours the campaign takes, but that changes the official difficulty to custom and, thus might be unable to unlock certain programs and other things. However, there's at least an endless mode where you can basically play forever and constantly beef up your characters to take on even beefier missions.I highly recommend this game as it is quite addicting! If you enjoyed Mark of the Ninja, Metal Gear Solid, or Tenchu, this, in my humble opinion, is the next level of the stealth genre. Just what's possible really makes this game unique. Tiniest drawback is that all maps reuse the same tiles and look the same at a distance, but at least the maps are randomized and so are always a fresh new experience in how to traverse them in each playthrough.This game is worth its full price, but if you can get it on sale, don't even think twice! Just get it!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												An absolute gem - clever, stylish, addictive.Going in I expected a bit of a power fantasy, as my solid snake type agents ran rings around a helpless bunch of guards. Instead it's one of the most tense games I've played. You can't leave a level the way you came in, so from the outset the clock is ticking, as even if you abandon your objective you still have to find the exit as the clock ticks down and your enemy becomes more capable. It's unforgiving, if an guard spots your agent you might have one chance to stop them getting permadeaded. In theory you can save them with medigel, but you won't because a) you won't have any medigel and b) you'll need another agent to get past the guard that just shot the first to apply it. Once you get off beginner difficulty this game is HARD.This works in its favour though. Every level completed feels like a true victory, especially if you manage to complete secondary objectives, outwit guards, or pull off narrow escapes. The game is also tough but very fair. The only randomness is in the proceedural level generation, so short of it generating a map where a guard or two immediately bursts into your starting room (which has happened to me about twice), if you make a mistake it's always your own fault. There are always multiple ways to accomplish goals, first of which is balancing speedagainst stealth, and until things go really, really bad there will be a way out if you're smart enough. The turn-based gameplay means most of the pressure is in your mind.It's gorgeous, with a clear aesthetic, and should run on just about any computer.It would be nice if upgrades and items were a bit more available and varied, to allow you to build a team based on specific approaches. The DLC seems to help with this a bit.Campaigns last 3-4 hours and there's plenty of replayability with a dozen-odd agents to pick from, the proceedurally generated levels and a variety of game modes.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												I'm writing this review coming off of the victory high from beating Experienced Mode, and as part of my task to write a review for those upcoming Steam Awards. My nomination for Invisible Inc: The "Just Five More Minutes" Award.I had no expectations when I first opened up this game. I only knew that it was part of the Klei Essentials collection and that it was up for cheap cheap. So I'm willing to call my first experience perfectly unhyped.And man am I happy with what I got. Invisible is an incredibly well-designed game, both graphically and technically. Each agent holds their own on the field, each Corporation has their own distinct theme which resonates well throughout their facilities, everything just seems to make sense within the context of the game. The gameplay itself is like a high-stakes chess game at its peaks, except all you've got is bishops which can't really take any enemy pieces, only slow them down (or, if you want to go lethal, END their corporate slave lives for good [YOU MONSTER]). The game teaches you with every loss and every restart: about itself, about the patterns of the enemies, about the various semi-random daemons which affect gameplay in new and interesting ways the more you hack the enemy systems.It's a glorious red-and-yellow dancefloor of danger spots that you're constantly learning to manuever without getting your shoes stomped. And I LOVE IT.Will the RNG bite you in the butt? Yes. Constantly. But never will it put you in an insurmountable situation. You will always have the opportunity to prepare for armored enemies. You will always have the ability to scout ahead before that guard walks into the spawn room on his regular patrol. You do not get to yell at the game for putting a guard in that room that you told your agent to walk into without scouting first. That's on YOU.Will it eventually get boring, having learned every enemy pattern, every room shape, every action and reaction possible by guards, drones, etc? Maybe. One day I might find myself without my classic evil mastermind cackling as I lure guards off of their patrol with the body of one of their comrades, directly into a waiting ambush by my agent behind the potted plant. I dread the day that I might grow bored of this game. But I don't see it happening anytime soon. I've logged 36 hours thus far, most of that accidental overnights as I urge my teams into the next mission, next mission, until the sun comes up and I go to eat a sad and sleepless breakfast, and I STILL find this game as fun as when I first booted it up.The plot? I'm willing to call it good. The voice acting is top-notch, animation sequences are well-done, the ending... is actually fitting when you think about it. But you're not there for the plot. You're there for the game. And the game is brutally fun.I recommend. Full force.

I've lost the entire game repeatedly on the first mission, having been swamped by enemies out of nowhere. The game can be fun, but you'll be driven mad by frustration having lost over and over and over and over again.

I would like to see an alternate universe career mode where the objectives following the installation of Incognito into the new mainframe (without her killling everyone) are not for the benefit of Invisible Inc., but for the detriment of the corporations. Money must still be acqured to obtain some gear, but other gear can be manufactured at your own HQ. At this point, because the corporations have realized Invisible Inc. did not fade away and is still going strong, security will be stronger and the levels larger, because it is more difficult to bypass the firewall. The main objective of this section of gameplay would be to evaluate ways to sabatoge the corporations and take them down one by one until they all fall. But because the corporations now know where you are, you will have to defend your base from time to time in reverse-spy missions. THAT is the game I want to see for this, not just the 3 day mission. Still, the 3 day mission is quite challenging in itself, just because of the length of the story, there isn't as much replay value for those who prefer story oriented games.Buy it on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 3, 2016
												I came into Invisible Inc. with the feeling that I'd be playing a tactical stealth game and departed with feeling like I was playing a lighter slightly less luck based X-Com. But that is hardly a bad thing. Invisible Inc. is a very strong title about fast-moving tactical stealth, full of customization options to benefit many different types of gameplay ranging from completely silent to brutal elimination.From the start of the campaign you're given three days to gather enough resources to mount a counterattack against a shadowy corporation (even shadowy-ier than the other four ruling the world). Every mission takes between 5 to 12 hours to reach, meaning you could do a bunch of nearby missions and get about four done in a day, or as little as two. Missions typically don't take much longer than 20 minutes in game time but are meaty enough to really get your mental muscles flexing. At the end of every successful (or unsuccessful) campaign, you earn XP which is translated into new starting agents and upgrades, all of which promoting various playstyles. On top of that the campaigns are relatively short (four and a half hours) meaning that there's a lot of room for trying these various gadgets and gizmos with minimal downtime. Another thing I greatly enjoyed is the modifiable difficulty, beginner difficulty is easy enough to get you in but still challenging enough to test you. As of writing, I haven't yet played the other difficulty levels, but I was greatly impressed by the first so I have high hopes for the rest.The DLC - Contigency Plan - adds an additional 48 hours to the campaign while adding a challenging mission to the middle of the game, not to mention a whole lot more stuff and challenges to overcome. If anything it feels like a warmup to Endless mode (which I'm actually excited to play, a first really) as it extends the game another 4 and a half hours while throwing harder security to deal with. Unfortunately the last mission doesn't seem to scale as well and I found it an embarrassing cakewalk to overcome where I was barely making it through the mid-campaign mission that was added. Overall I liked the additions, but also felt like the game hit its stride when you had minimal resources to work with.So all said and done, Invisible Inc. is an incredibly strong title that also happens to be pretty cheap to boot. It surprised me, feeling like an overall enjoyable game. I'm hoping they do a little more with it, but am okay if they don't. Recommended for full price, DLC is totally optional, but synergizes well with the main game so it's up to you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												Invisible Inc is an intense turn based strategy game about infiltrating corporations and staying alive. You start off with two agents (you can get more as the game progresses) who have limited resources and, quite frankly, are pretty weak. As you infiltrate facilities, you can buy new gear, augments (which are basically power ups) and programs for your AI, Incognita. For a turn based strategy, it is rather fast paced. The alarm level escalates slowly even if you aren’t spotted in your turn which adds an extra layer of pressure to the game play.PROS:The graphics are great. They are cartoony, but the style works perfectly with the darker, ominous, cyberpunk look of the surroundings. It is challenging, even on the beginner difficulty. This is a pro because it is a lot more rewarding when you complete a mission that you have previously failed.The controls are easy. It takes a while to adjust to the gameplay, but the controls are very easy to pick up and use.There is a wide variety of gear. It is not limited to guns and tasers, there is a variety of other gadgets like adrenalin shots, distraction devices and even an EMP.The gameplay outside the mission is engaging. You have to choose targets around the world, buy/sell items from your contact and manage your agents.The voice actors are great. There is no shortage of dialogue in this game and it adds a lot the ste personality of some simple animations (my personal favorite is Monst3r)As you get stronger/faster/more efficient, the guards will to. You will encounter guards with armor and augments of their own. There are even drones that you can hack.The game is very entertaining/addicting. It’s worth the money, you will come back to the game time and time again.CONS:The gameplay is relatively short. There is plenty to do in the game, but once you complete beginner difficulty, the missions in experienced mode are the same except for the added difficulty. If you buy it with Contingency Plan, you won’t have this problem.Though the worlds are randomly generated, there isn’t a huge variety of how your surroundings look. There are four very subtle changes (they vary depending what corporation you’re infiltrating) but otherwise, the setting is the same. Fundamentally, the game is phenomenal. I would highly recommend it. Put it on your wishlist and get it when it goes on sale. It’s thoroughly entertaining and worth every penny.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 11
 DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine Invisible, Inc. is a game developed and published by Klei Entertainment, the same people behind Mark of the Ninja. Invisible, Inc. is simply one of the best single-player games I've ever playedThe theme is evoked well and the mechanisms of play are finely tuned. The real genius though, lies in how the game handles mistakes. In many games failure just costs time, or you are forced to reload whenever you make a mistakeInvisible, Inc. also allows this, but it really shines when you set up a game without rewinds or reloads. Then you get to experience how good a game can really beThe perfectly executed stealthy infiltration can quickly become a deadly game of cat and mouse, and successfully pulling unconscious agents out of a botched operation is way more satisfying than a reload could ever bePoints of reference could be XCOM or the best roguelikes, but I think Invisible, Inc. outclasses them allMy only criticism lies with how certain equipment can make core elements of the game trivial to overcome. It's not so fun when you have a "super agent" able to avoid or overcome all oppositionThe relatively short campaign time-frame and random item availability prevents this from becoming a significant problem though RECOMMENDED :)

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												This game is a turn by turn strategy where a couple of spy try to infiltrate a complex, with a gameplay very close to the X-com games : you mouve a couple of guys, get info, stun enemies, then the computer play and you start again. If you like strategy and intersting micro-management, this game is for you.I really like Invisible Ink, which is for me the elegent version of X-com two. There is less content, less graphics, less super-powers, but the ones that exists have intersting interaction, and therefore the gameplay is funnier than the one in the X-com series.- first randomness is correctly managed. No unlucky shots, or bad luck when performing and action. Everything you do will work, but the enemy reaction and the level layout are randoms. This is definitively a good decision as it create the illusion that the enemy has a plan, and it makes exploration crucial.- then, exploration is fun, as it's a poker game : the more you explore, the better decision you'll take and the more loot you will gain, but the more time you will loose. And time (in fact turns) are a precious ressource : as time passes, the enemy gets stronger and you'll have more gards, more enemy programs and harder hacking to handle.- then the game is more readable : this is simple 2D, with simple cover, and simple actions. You don't have to try everything 10 times to understand how it works. Things just do what's written in the description, that's intuitive and cool. Difficulties comes from poker and interaction, not from hard to understand interface.So if you like strategy, you'll like this game.Here comes the usual paragraph about music and graphics. In fe words, they do the job. Graphics are cool, with a style that fits perfectly well in a High-tech spy game and easy to read. There is no anoying stuff (like bad rotating camera, useless details, anoying particles, fog or whatever graphics cards sellers likes, but gamers hate), and no creative or awsome things. And the music is the same way : minimal ambiant.And now, here is the paragraph about the invisible pink unicorn. She's in the game, but you cannot see her, as she's as invisible as the ink. But as she's pink, we're pretty sure that the invisible ink is pink.

Posted: December 14, 2016
												An excellent stealth centered, turn based roguelike game where each choice matters. The game does not joke about you having odds stacked against you in a direct firefight, instead you must use sneaky tactics to get around complex you infiltrated, get the objective and get out ASAP. Truly managed to captivate the hit and run tactic used by small agencies.However, speed as well as being undetected is the key. You will not remain undeteced forever as the security level increases over time, moreso if you are caught. Invisible Inc strikes a nice balance between having to be fast and stealthy, a quality that gives a healthy gameYour squad is also accompanied by a powerful AI, that playes a major role in your success by being able to manipulate facility devices to serve you instead but beware, they are protected and sometimes you need to think about your resource allocationI also highly recommend getting the DLC, contigeancy plan. It adds a bunch of items and characters to make the game more varied, opening up even more strategies and interesting synergies. It's only 4€ if bought in a bundle and well worth the small priceThe downside of this game however is  that if you are not familiar with stealth or strategy games, then Invisible inc can be quite difficult to pick up and learn as the tutorial is quite honestly lacking finer important details which you will discover as you play. Thus I recommend starting up from the easiest difficulty (it still provides a decent challenge) and move up until you hit the hardest difficulties, which is what the game balance is centered around and what defines the true invisible inc experienceAs a final word: Try to save knockouts and kills until the last moment where you absolutely need to do so and use the corpse drag option to prevent guards from waking up

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 3, 2016
												I came into Invisible Inc. with the feeling that I'd be playing a tactical stealth game and departed with feeling like I was playing a lighter slightly less luck based X-Com. But that is hardly a bad thing. Invisible Inc. is a very strong title about fast-moving tactical stealth, full of customization options to benefit many different types of gameplay ranging from completely silent to brutal elimination.From the start of the campaign you're given three days to gather enough resources to mount a counterattack against a shadowy corporation (even shadowy-ier than the other four ruling the world). Every mission takes between 5 to 12 hours to reach, meaning you could do a bunch of nearby missions and get about four done in a day, or as little as two. Missions typically don't take much longer than 20 minutes in game time but are meaty enough to really get your mental muscles flexing. At the end of every successful (or unsuccessful) campaign, you earn XP which is translated into new starting agents and upgrades, all of which promoting various playstyles. On top of that the campaigns are relatively short (four and a half hours) meaning that there's a lot of room for trying these various gadgets and gizmos with minimal downtime. Another thing I greatly enjoyed is the modifiable difficulty, beginner difficulty is easy enough to get you in but still challenging enough to test you. As of writing, I haven't yet played the other difficulty levels, but I was greatly impressed by the first so I have high hopes for the rest.The DLC - Contigency Plan - adds an additional 48 hours to the campaign while adding a challenging mission to the middle of the game, not to mention a whole lot more stuff and challenges to overcome. If anything it feels like a warmup to Endless mode (which I'm actually excited to play, a first really) as it extends the game another 4 and a half hours while throwing harder security to deal with. Unfortunately the last mission doesn't seem to scale as well and I found it an embarrassing cakewalk to overcome where I was barely making it through the mid-campaign mission that was added. Overall I liked the additions, but also felt like the game hit its stride when you had minimal resources to work with.So all said and done, Invisible Inc. is an incredibly strong title that also happens to be pretty cheap to boot. It surprised me, feeling like an overall enjoyable game. I'm hoping they do a little more with it, but am okay if they don't. Recommended for full price, DLC is totally optional, but synergizes well with the main game so it's up to you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												To start of, this is probably my favourite game on steam right now.As i like tactical games, this one fits the bill perfectly.The one thing i like most, is that can avoid situations where you need to depend on your chances, like in X-Com, when your 95 % shot misses and because of that, your whole team dies. If your team dies here, it was probably your fault.That is because you have a very high amount of control over what happens. The guards path can be predicted, you can hack  everything that would make your life hard, if you got the resources.Another thing i like is the possibilitys you have. Before every playthrough, you choose two agents and two programs to start with. The are combinations that are quite safe, but not the only one working. You can also go for risk. Those are pretty dependant on luck, and with enough badluck can end a run despite all skill you can put up. Also, you can decide to stay in the level a tad longer to loot more, but then permanently ramping up of the security will make it more difficult to get out alive.Ok, back to standard categories:Gameplay:Solid, nothing exceptional, but that is not what makes this game so good. There are tools at your disposal like the tactic-screen to increase overview, etc.Graphics:Funktional, but nice enough that you don't get tired of looking at them. Story:Almost non existent. In every run, you follow the same pattern with the exact same voicelines at the exact same points. You get compormised, build your forces in secret and after your time runs out, you tackle the "bosslevel". Summary:If you expect a story, keep your fingers of the game, it will just dissappoint you. If you're looking for something tactial with a high level of control that has the potential to melt your brain from overheating, your at the right place. And for those who like living with their brain intact, there are enough possibilities to play somewhat more casually.Well then, thanks for reading.Cheerio

Posted: December 13, 2016
												Easy mode makes you feel like a superspy badass and is easy to get through while still feeling challenging. Then you try Experienced or Expert and the difficulty _really_ gets ramped up. As you complete playthroughs (successful or not) you will gain XP to unlock new agents and alternate versions for some agents. This allows for a good amount of replay value since different agent combinations will lead to vastly different playstyles. Even the same agent can feel very different from between playthoughs depending on what items and augments you give to them. The framing story is nice but nothing special, after your first playthough you will find yourself skipping through the voiceover bits between missions. (There's not a lot though)I would definitely recommend getting with the Contingency Plan DLC as it basically doubles the length of the storyline and adds a good number of useful weapons and extra agents.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												Incredible stealth TBS game. Difficulty ramps up at a good clip and resources are limited so you are forced to balance what you want to bring vs. what you need to bring while still leaving space for future upgrades and for objectives. Enemies are distinct and interesting, which caused me to focus on particular corporations that my team was better suited for. Despite what some negative reviews state, there is always a way to beat a level. You just may not be able to find it. I've repeatedly had all my agents down but one, max alarm, guards everywhere, etc. and still beat the level without losing anyone permanently. It's also a nice feature that if you do leave behind an agent, you can always break them out of a prison on a later mission.tldr: Brilliant game. Get it if you have the brainpower and patience for it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												This game is a turn by turn strategy where a couple of spy try to infiltrate a complex, with a gameplay very close to the X-com games : you mouve a couple of guys, get info, stun enemies, then the computer play and you start again. If you like strategy and intersting micro-management, this game is for you.I really like Invisible Ink, which is for me the elegent version of X-com two. There is less content, less graphics, less super-powers, but the ones that exists have intersting interaction, and therefore the gameplay is funnier than the one in the X-com series.- first randomness is correctly managed. No unlucky shots, or bad luck when performing and action. Everything you do will work, but the enemy reaction and the level layout are randoms. This is definitively a good decision as it create the illusion that the enemy has a plan, and it makes exploration crucial.- then, exploration is fun, as it's a poker game : the more you explore, the better decision you'll take and the more loot you will gain, but the more time you will loose. And time (in fact turns) are a precious ressource : as time passes, the enemy gets stronger and you'll have more gards, more enemy programs and harder hacking to handle.- then the game is more readable : this is simple 2D, with simple cover, and simple actions. You don't have to try everything 10 times to understand how it works. Things just do what's written in the description, that's intuitive and cool. Difficulties comes from poker and interaction, not from hard to understand interface.So if you like strategy, you'll like this game.Here comes the usual paragraph about music and graphics. In fe words, they do the job. Graphics are cool, with a style that fits perfectly well in a High-tech spy game and easy to read. There is no anoying stuff (like bad rotating camera, useless details, anoying particles, fog or whatever graphics cards sellers likes, but gamers hate), and no creative or awsome things. And the music is the same way : minimal ambiant.And now, here is the paragraph about the invisible pink unicorn. She's in the game, but you cannot see her, as she's as invisible as the ink. But as she's pink, we're pretty sure that the invisible ink is pink.

Mean Mr. Mustard's short Invisible, Inc. review 1) Essential - buy it NOW 2) Recommended - buy it on sale 3) AvoidTime to complete – 5 hours to complete campaign on 'Beginner' difficultyPlayed multiplayer? N/AWorth revisiting? Yes, game is designed to be replayed multiple times, with new unlocks and increased difficulty levels offered as an incentiveBest part – The way the game is designed to encourage repeat playthroughs is what makes Invisible, Inc. unique in the turn-based stealth genre and provides an addictive and satisfying gameplay loop.Worst part – Missions do not have a lot of variety and can become repetitive. I found limiting myself to one or two missions per play session helped alleviate any possible monotony.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
												This is another winner from Klei - a great, challenging, and surprisingly deep turn-based strategy game. I did find that the initial learning curve was a little steep, and so recommend that beginners actually do not select the Beginner difficulty. Instead, dig through the custom settings and dial up the multiplier for the # of credits you get for hacking / stealing, and increase the KO amount for the guards. This helped tremendously, as even with the Beginner difficulty, I was always getting killed after just the 2nd or 3rd mission.Once you get past the first few hours, and start to learn all the ways your agents can die (and oh yes, they will die, repeatedly!), then you begin to see just how much depth there is to the game. This game really reminds me of some of the best Euro-board games, such as Tikal, Catan, etc. The thing that makes these games great is the vast amount of choices you have on any given turn, and the very small amount of actions you actually have time to perform. Of course in Invisible, Inc., as you progress, you will gain the ability to gain more actions, but the central strategic element of balancing all of those choices to maximize your outcome still remains.I foresee a great # of hours put into this game before the year is out.

												After playing 86 hours of this game i've finally completed Invisible Inc + Contingency plan on experienced difficulty, possibly one of the best and also most frustrating games i have ever played. I think iv got to pretty solid grips with it now but thats after nearly 90hours of gameplay and i have yet to even try my hand at expert difficulty. However if you love testing yourself against punishingly hard games, and particularly if you like stealth games this is the game for you.Also Buy the DLC, it makes the main campaign slightly harder by making it longer, but all the additional items/characters/programs etc. make it a much more intricate game.Good luck!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												With all its different agents, augments, skills, and items there is a lot to explore. Tons of replay value, as every mission is procuderally generated so you never get the same map twice.I'm also loving the alarm system. Each turn, the counter increases, so that every five turns the alarm level is raised and a new security feature is implemented. It forces you to be faster; you have to know when to leave and decide if looting that last safe over there is /really/ worth it.If you don't like that though, you can just turn it off. There is a great amount of customization options so for anyone who is failing Experienced difficulty like me - don't worry, you can simply get rid of the thing that causes you to fail. Put more power stations into each level, make the maps smaller, disable the automatically increasing alarm, place more safes to loot. Whatever it is that frustrates you; you can get rid of it with one click.10/10 would absolutely recommend if you like strategy games.

content:
Posted: February 6
												Fantastic game. The gameplay is tense and suspenseful, the visuals and atmosphere are great, but what impressed me the most is the way the game breaks new ground in terms of stealth games. The developers have taken a bunch of familiar mechanics and combined them in such a way that it does something entirely new. I rate it up there with Dwarf Fortress and Minecraft as one of those games that manages to carve out a new genre.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 8
												Like Mark of the Ninja and Don't Starve, this is another outstanding game by Klei Entertainment. It takes elements of stealth games, XCOM, Shadowrun and rogue-likes and merges them together to create a tense strategy game about a secret agency that infiltrates companies in a dystopian future.While there is an enjoyable main plot in the campaign, the main focus of the game lies in it's gameplay. Its rogue-like nature, its random elements and the fact that the campaign is not too long (without the DLC at least) let's you enjoy the game multiple times even after you have beaten it the first time. IF you have beaten it. I say that because the game can be really brutal at times (in a really enjoyable way). Unlike many rogue-likes, the game is very accessible and not too complex but the depth it achieves by combining all its elements is great. While permadeath and limited ways to undo mistakes appeal to rogue-like fans, the game is highly customizable and you can enable retries and rewinds to make the game easier for you if you like.Apart from the good gameplay and the clean UI, the music is amazing and adds to the tension. Starting out relatively quite it ramps up and when everything goes down in flames on the screen, the music let's you know. And everything will go down in flames. Every game. Even if you think you have everything under control, something will happen. Part of the fun is getting out of these situations unharmed.If you dig strategic games, rogue-lites, and stealth games you should definitely check out Invisible Inc. I did not think I would enjoy the game as much as I do, but I tried it anyways because I liked Klei's previous games and was not disappointed. It does a lot of things right and checks enough boxes for me to let me do "just one more mission".

content:
Posted: February 20
												This is an excellent turn-based strategy and infiltration game. The story, though short, is intriguing, and the gameplay is easy to pick up and deep in its mechanics. It has high replayability value and I never felt as though I was out of danger. I only wish that they had spent more time fleshing out the details of this new, corporate-controlled world and doing a little more world building. The art style is cool and stylish and really striking, a sort of a mix between polygonal art and that Erin mascot from Esurance. I highly recommend giving the game a try, especially if you can get it as part of a bundle.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 21
												Very surprised so few people on my friends list is up on this game. Definitely the most enjoyable turn based game I've played in a good long while. I actually think the mechanics and unique characters make this an even better package than X-Com 2. It's certainly more unique. I love how they managed to get both hacking and stealth to work so seemlessly in a turn based game. The campaign isn't anything ground breaking and isn't even close to being as well designed as Hitman to show off how much is actually part of the package. It requires a lot of patience early on, but once you start to understand the systems, it shines as a strategy game. These days, it doesn't seem to matter what type of game Klei releases. They stay winning.

content:
Posted: February 26
												A very fun game.  Standard cyber-distopia, turn based strategy.  There's a turn limit, as the "alarm" level keeps creeping up each turn.  It can go shooting up if you act indiscretely.A little hard to try to ghost each level, and if you're there for too long the guards are alerted each turn to where your characters are.  You can use lethal methods to keep the guards permently down, but that tends to increase the alert levels.  Non-lethal results in guards getting up a few turns after getting knocked out.  You can keep them knocked out by using an agent to pin them.  But then you're down an agent that you need exploring the map.The goal is to steal enough supplies from each mission, while completing the primary objective.  I suggest playing on Beginner to get the hang of the game, and then ramp it up to suit your abilities.  Enjoyed the game and the story line.

												I first played this during a free to play weekend and was completely hooked. The game would be very short without Contingency Plan. I definitely recommend the bundle. Main plot is the same each playthrough, but you can choose which type of mission to pursue and levels are randomly generated. Also, different agents have different abilities for good replayablility. Great turn-based infiltration game! Please make Invisible 2!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 18
												It's like XCom and Mark of the Ninja had a child together - a turn-based stealth game where you try to infiltrate corporations with your squad of hackers, and whatnot. The campaign is short-ish - it took me about 6 hours to get through the beginner mode. However, the game is extremely replayable, with you unlocking different characters / items / programs every game - somewhat like Dungeon of the Endless. Multiple different difficulty levels exist as well as custom games, which give you a tonne of options.The artstyle is awesome - it's somehow both typical Klei (Don't Starve, Mark of the Ninja) while being completely unique from both of those titles.All in all, this is a fantastic game. Even after just playing Beginner Mode, I'm totally sold on it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												Like any rouge strategy game you're going to get ♥♥♥♥ed from not knowing better and the rng. This game spices it up focusing on stealth, hacking and...outright tile abuse!The difficulties make you have to die a lot before you realize how you need to play in order to beat it, the game is short though. Too short actually, the game is meant to rush you but, i find it hard to build my team into anything i want by the end.There are a lot of upgrades to find and youll only have access to a select few. Thats not the problem tho, the fact is that most of the upgrades you can find are complete garabage. Now you can sell them for half price but, thats assuming you stole it, which is a let down either way.Basically its in your best intrest to browse every type of upgrade station you come across. You might get killed not having it, you might get killed trying to get it.Maybe im just too used to them but, the starting agents and programs seem to be the best starting kit. Not just easiest to play but, the most practical.The game is better than good but, its not great either, its definately missing some polishing. Hard to tell if i even want to get the dlc expansion. It looks more or less the same, add new things in, strat changes, get ♥♥♥♥ed for not knowing better.5 out of 10 dameons

content:
Posted: April 26
												It's a great game, simple as that. The easiest difficulty is hard enough not to be boring, but easy enough to learn the controls and mechanics. The next one is a bit of a challenge, but not frustratingly so. And then it goes full on permadeath FTL-style and screws you over for every little mistake. I love it. They teach you everything, and then throw you in the deep end.If you like very hard games with a resonable learning curve, and stealth games, try this. It's great. The story is nice too, but I much prefer the nice gameplay. Especially since killing people is usually a bad option, and neutralizing them temporarily is much more effective. I always enjoy games that encourage a clean job.
